channel.title: HackerLabs - A blog by Deepak Kandepet
channel.description: Links and Articles from HackerLabs.org, A blog by Deepak Kandepet.

item.title: Detecting similar and identical images using perseptual hashes
item.description: Use a perseptual hashing algorithm (pHash) to create an image signature that can be used to detect similar and identical images. Compare pHash against other duplicate detection algorithms like color histograms, average hashing, multi-resolution Haar wavelet decomposition etc. Finally, build a tool that can organize photos based on their (EXIF) creation date, but skips/marks identical images using pHash signature.

item.title: From bits to waves - The inner workings of an ethernet controller
item.description: Hack into an Ethernet Network Interface Controller (NIC) and understand the intricate details of how the Intel 82559 transmits and receives digital data across a CAT5 cable. Understand the internals of the eepro100 Linux driver and how it interfaces with the linux kernel on one side and the NIC on the other side.

item.title: Hacking Lucene - The Index format
item.description: Understand the basics of search engine indexing and inverted indexes. Delve deep into the internals of Lucene 3.4 Index and how it helps with full text searches. Get intimate with Index building and using inverted index to execute search queries.

item.title: How big of a haystack do you need to hide?
item.description: Every fact you learn about a person reduces the entropy of their identity. Find out how some basic information gathered from your browser can uniquely identify you from a population of 6.5 billion.

item.title: God's number is 20, mine is 67.
item.description: The term "God's number" is the minimum number of turns required to solve a Rubik's cube from an arbitrary starting position (i.e., in the worst case). Rokicki et al. (2010) used a Google supercomputer and 35 CPU-years to determine God's number to be 20. Without using magic or trickery, the best I can do is 67. Learn one of the most common algorithms to solve the Rubik's cube.
